feed.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors

entry.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors
entry.summary:
The Bitcoin development community has engaged in comprehensive discussions regarding the appointment of new Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) editors, focusing on broadening the expertise and perspectives within the editorial team. Murch and Roasbeef have been identified as prime candidates for their openness to Bitcoin experimentation, which is crucial for considering a diverse array of proposals impartially. The conversation underscores the importance of having editors with experience in programming languages beyond C++ to enhance compatibility across different Bitcoin clients and operational layers, suggesting a move towards a more independent BIP repository to facilitate smoother operations.
A notable emphasis has been placed on diversifying the pool of BIP editors to include individuals from varied geographical and cultural backgrounds, thus ensuring a comprehensive approach to proposal review and responsiveness. This diversity also extends to linguistic skills, deemed beneficial for translating complex technical concepts into English. Concerns have been raised about the potential overlap between BIP editor roles and other responsibilities within the Bitcoin community, highlighting the necessity for editors to possess not just technical knowledge but also copy-editing proficiency and a proven track record within the Bitcoin ecosystem.
Jon Atack, Reuben Somsen, Kanzure, and Roasbeef are recognized for their unique strengths and proposed contributions to the BIP editorial role, with their selection based on competence and suitability. Their backgrounds feature significant involvement in Bitcoin development and open-source contributions, demonstrating a commitment to adhering to the guidelines outlined in BIP 2 for responsible management of improvement proposals.
However, reservations exist regarding Tonoski's candidacy due to his lack of interest in understanding the historical rationale behind technical decisions and his excessively zealous approach. The dialogue suggests modifying the BIP process to democratize the assessment of technical viability and encourage community engagement in the non-developer triage of BIPs, aiming to speed up the editorial process and address challenges such as delays in assigning numbers and merging approved changes.
The discussions have also touched on the need for a more robust review mechanism to scrutinize BIPs effectively, pointing out the current bottleneck caused by insufficient bandwidth. Suggestions for adding more editors include experimenting with non-developer involvement in triaging tasks, with Jon Atack and Roasbeef mentioned as potential candidates despite concerns about Roasbeef’s suitability. The role of a BIP editor is highlighted as critical for the structured development of the Bitcoin protocol, requiring a meticulous review process to ensure submissions meet the community's standards and guidelines.
Moreover, Luke Dashjr has been suggested to be responsible for selecting new BIP editors, with Kanzure and RubenSomsen identified as fitting candidates expected to benefit the developer community by streamlining the BIP process. The introduction of more editors is seen as essential for alleviating the backlog of BIP submissions and enhancing the overall efficiency of the process, with a consensus on the numbering scheme of BIPs being vital for maintaining the integrity and consistency of the BIP process.
